This section of the Annual Report FY23-24 of Gokaldas Exports Limited outlines the accounting policies related to assets held for sale, government grants, taxes on income, and property, plant, and equipment (PPE).  

**Assets Held for Sale:** An asset is classified as held for sale when it is available for immediate sale in its present condition, its sale is highly probable, and it will genuinely be sold, not abandoned. The sale is considered highly probable when management is committed to a sale plan, an active program to locate a buyer has been initiated, the asset is actively marketed at a reasonable price, the sale is expected to be completed within one year, and there are no likely significant changes to the plan. Assets held for sale are measured at the lower of their carrying amount and fair value less costs to sell and are presented separately in the consolidated balance sheet.

**Government Grants:** Government grants are recognized when there is reasonable assurance that the conditions attached to them will be complied with and the grants will be received. Grants related to assets are treated as income in the Consolidated Statement of Profit and Loss upon fulfilment of the conditions, and are presented in the Consolidated Balance Sheet by deducting the grant from the carrying amount of the asset. Grants related to revenue are recognized systematically in the statement of profit and loss to match them with the related costs they are intended to compensate. Export incentives are recognized on an accrual basis according to the schemes formulated by the Government of India, provided there is reasonable assurance of compliance with the attached conditions.

**Taxes on Income:** Tax expense includes current and deferred tax. Current income tax is based on the taxable profit for the year, calculated using enacted or substantively enacted tax rates and laws. Current income tax related to items recognized outside profit or loss is recognized in other comprehensive income (OCI) or equity. Deferred tax is recognized on differences between the carrying values of assets and liabilities and their tax bases, using the balance sheet liability model. Deferred tax assets are recognized to the extent that future taxable profits will be available to utilize temporary differences, unused tax credits, and tax losses. Deferred tax assets and liabilities are measured at the tax rates expected to apply when the asset is realized or the liability is settled, based on enacted or substantively enacted tax rates and laws. Deferred tax assets and liabilities are offset if there is a legally enforceable right to set off current tax assets against current tax liabilities and they relate to the same taxable entity and taxation authority. Minimum Alternative Tax (MAT) paid in India is recognized as a deferred tax asset if it is probable that future economic benefits will be realized.

**Property, Plant and Equipment (PPE):** On transitioning to Ind AS, Gokaldas Exports Limited elected to continue with the carrying value of its PPE as of March 31, 2016, measured according to previous GAAP, as the deemed cost on April 1, 2016. Freehold land is carried at historical cost and is not depreciated. Capital work-in-progress and other PPE are stated at historical cost less accumulated depreciation and impairment losses. Historical cost includes directly attributable acquisition expenditures. Subsequent costs are included in the asset’s carrying amount or recognized as a separate asset when future economic benefits are probable and the cost can be measured reliably. Components with significantly different useful lives are depreciated separately, while other repairs and maintenance are charged to profit and loss as incurred.
